article:
'Wiley Scribner' (September 6, 1840â€“September 28, 1889) "Chicago Daily
News," (1872-1963), September 29, 1889, pg. 11 'Proceedings of the
Illinois State Bar Association, Volumn 13, Part 1890, pg. 34 was a United
States politician and acting governor of Montana Territory from 1869 to 1870. [http://www.worldstatesmen.org/US_states_L-
M.html Data base]

Born in Jacksonville, Illinois, Scribner grew up in Fair Play, Wisconsin, in
Grant County, Wisconsin, where he became postmaster and was a merchant. He was
admitted to the bar. Scribner served in the 16th Wisconsin Volunteer Infantry
Regiment during the American Civil War. In 1866, he was elected to the Wisconsin
State Assembly. Scribner moved to Montana Territory, where he became a newspaper
editor and eventually became secretary of Montana Territory and acting governor
of the territory. In 1873, he moved to Chicago, Illinois, where he practiced law
and became clerk of the probate court. Scribner was a Republican. In 1884,
Scribner was elected recorder of deeds for Cook County, Illinois serving until
his death. "History of Chicago," vol 3, Alfred Theodore Andreas, 1886, pg.
247 [http://www.genealogytrails.com/ill/cook/earlysettlerobits.html
Obituaries of Early Settlers]
categories: People of Wisconsin in the American Civil War
Members of the Wisconsin State Assembly
